prior_works.title: Label Enhancement: Recovering Label Distributions from Logical Labels
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Defines the LE problem of inferring label distributions from logical multi-labels, providing the task setting and motivation that PROM directly addresses with a new probabilistic ranking-based formulation.

prior_works.title: Label Distribution Learning
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the notion of label distributions as targets, motivating the need to model principled links between distributions and rankings that PROM formalizes via orderliness and monotonicity.

prior_works.title: Multilabel Classification via Calibrated Label Ranking
prior_works.authors: Johannes Fürnkranz; Eyke Hüllermeier; Eneldo Loza Mencia; Klaus Brinker
prior_works.role: Demonstrated benefits of label ranking for multi-label tasks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows that learning pairwise label preferences and calibrating them can improve multi-label prediction, directly inspiring PROM’s use of label ranking signals to enhance label distributions.

prior_works.title: Pairwise Preference Learning and Ranking
prior_works.role: Methodological basis for pairwise label ranking
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the pairwise decomposition framework for ranking, underpinning PROM’s pairwise modeling of inter-label comparisons when inferring distribution-consistent rankings.

prior_works.title: Rank Analysis of Incomplete Block Designs: The Method of Paired Comparisons
prior_works.authors: Ralph Allan Bradley; Milton E. Terry
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a monotone logistic link between latent scores and pairwise win probabilities, a core probabilistic mechanism mirrored in PROM’s monotonicity assumption relating label intensities to comparison probabilities.

prior_works.title: On Extending the Bradley–Terry Model to Incorporate Ties in Paired Comparisons
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Extends pairwise probability models to allow ties, directly informing PROM’s treatment of equally important labels within its ranking–distribution linkage.

prior_works.title: The Analysis of Permutations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes a probability model over rankings that is orderly with respect to latent utilities, influencing PROM’s orderliness assumption connecting consistent rankings to underlying label probabilities.

synthesis_narrative: PROM’s core contribution—deriving a probabilistic bridge from label distributions to label rankings under explicit orderliness and monotonicity, while accommodating ties—rests on two converging lines of prior work. From the label-distribution side, Geng’s formulations of label distribution learning (LDL) and label enhancement (LE) established the objective of recovering nuanced label intensities from coarse multi-label annotations, but left open how to rigorously exploit ranking information during enhancement. From the ranking side, classical preference-learning and probabilistic ranking models supplied the missing mathematical tools. The pairwise preference framework of Fürnkranz and Hüllermeier provided a scalable decomposition for learning inter-label relations, while calibrated label ranking demonstrated that pairwise rankings can be converted into calibrated signals beneficial for multi-label prediction—motivating their use for reconstructing label distributions. At the probabilistic level, the Bradley–Terry model introduced a monotone link between latent scores and pairwise win probabilities, and Davidson’s extension incorporated ties, directly aligning with PROM’s need to map differences (or equality) in label intensities to probabilities of >, =, and < relations. Finally, the Plackett–Luce family grounded an orderly connection between latent utilities and full rankings, reinforcing PROM’s orderliness assumption. Together, these works enabled PROM to formalize a principled, probabilistic, pairwise mechanism that faithfully encodes how label distributions imply ranking relations—complete with monotonicity and tie handling—and to leverage these constraints for more accurate label enhancement.
